story.text:
Sam loved to walk. He liked hearing the birds sing and feeling the wind on his face.
One sunny day, he walked so far that he found a big, green forest. The trees were so tall they tickled the clouds.
Suddenly, two little creatures appeared!
Chipper the squirrel waved his fluffy tail.
“Hi there! Follow me! I’ll teach you how to climb a tree!” he squeaked.
Aaron the groundhog popped out of a hole and said,
“Don’t climb trees! Come see my home underground. It’s warm and cozy!”

Sam followed Chipper and started to climb the big oak tree.
“Hold on tight!” Chipper called. “Use your feet, not just your hands!”
When Sam reached the top, the forest spread out like a green ocean.
He could see his house far away!
“Look there!” said Chipper. “A bird’s nest! Do you want to peek inside?”

Sam crept closer and peeked into the nest.
Inside were three tiny, blue eggs. “They look like little sky marbles,” he whispered.
Then—whoosh!—a mama bird flew back!
“Chirp! Chirp!” she cried, flapping her wings.

transitions.text: Try to talk to the bird

story.text:
“I’m sorry, little bird,” Sam said softly.
The bird blinked and chirped again, but not angrily this time.
Chipper handed him a shiny acorn. “For being kind,” he said.
The moss beneath their feet glowed faintly as if approving his choice.
Sam realized he was really hot.

“Hello,” Sam said. “I didn’t mean to scare you.”
The bird fluttered her wings and dropped a soft feather at his feet.
“Wow!” said Sam. “She gave me a gift!”
Sunlight danced on the feather, making rainbow patterns on the ground.

Sam shook his head. “I don’t want to bother the birds.”
“Good choice!” said Chipper. “Let’s find something yummy instead!”
They climbed down and shared berries from a bush.

Sam decided to visit Aaron’s home.
Aaron led him through tall grass to a cave under a tree root.
Inside, it was warm and smelled like dirt and pine needles.
“I’ll grab some water,” said Aaron. “Make yourself comfy!”
Sam looked around at the tiny twig chairs.
Then he turned—and the door had closed!
Sam ran his fingers along the wall and found a small tunnel.

Sam knocked on the door. “Aaron? Are you there?”
The door opened, and Aaron smiled. “Sorry! It got stuck.”
He handed Sam some cool water, and they laughed together.
The shadows in the cave seemed to retreat as laughter filled the room.

Sam sat down on a mossy rug.
He heard soft snoring—Aaron had fallen asleep!
Sam yawned and curled up, too.
Outside, the forest whispered gently, a lullaby of rustling leaves.

Sam followed Chipper and Aaron down a narrow trail that split into two tunnels.
The air was cool and smelled like pine needles.
One tunnel glowed with golden light, while the other was dark and echoed with dripping water.
Aaron twitched his nose. “The bright one leads to the heart of the forest.”

The tunnel opened into a wide, sparkling chamber filled with roots that glowed like lanterns.
“Wow!” Sam whispered. “It’s beautiful!”
In the middle stood a small wooden box carved with forest symbols.
Chipper tilted his head. “Should we open it?”

The dark tunnel grew colder and narrower.
Water dripped down the walls, and something small skittered ahead.
Sam crouched, shining his flashlight—two glowing eyes blinked back!
It was only a frog… or was it? The croak echoed like words: “Go back.”

Sam slowly lifted the lid of the wooden box.
Inside was a single golden key resting on a bed of moss.
When he picked it up, the roots around them shimmered and pulsed.
Aaron whispered, “That’s the Forest Key. It opens paths meant to stay hidden.”

Sam shook his head. “Let’s not touch it.”
Chipper nodded quickly. “Good idea. Forest boxes can be tricky.”
As they turned to leave, the lights in the roots dimmed one by one.
The tunnel behind them closed, sealing with soft earth.
They had no choice but to go deeper.

Sam turned around, heart pounding.
The tunnel walls seemed closer now, whispering softly in the dark.
When he finally crawled out, sunlight felt like a miracle.
Aaron laughed. “Guess that tunnel didn’t like visitors!”

Sam kept crawling until the tunnel opened into a crystal cave.
Glittering gems reflected his flashlight, painting the walls in rainbow colors.
He touched one—and it sang!
A low, humming note filled the air, and suddenly the cave trembled.

Sam placed the key against a nearby root, and a door appeared!
Warm light spilled out, and a faint melody drifted through.
He stepped inside and found a treehouse filled with glowing books.
Each page whispered stories of forest adventures long forgotten.

Sam tucked the key into his pocket and smiled.
“I’ll save it for later,” he said.
As they left the chamber, the light behind them flickered, and the forest seemed to sigh.
Something told him the forest would remember him now.

The tunnel sloped downward until it opened into a moonlit cavern.
A pool of water shimmered in the center, glowing softly.
Chipper dipped his paw in and gasped. “It’s warm!”
Sam smiled. “A secret spring.” They sat beside it, resting as the forest sang above.

Sam ran as the crystal cave shook violently.
Rocks tumbled down, but he dove through the exit just in time.
Behind him, the entrance collapsed, sealing the strange song forever.
Aaron popped out of the ground nearby. “You made it!” he said, grinning.

Sam listened, mesmerized, as the humming turned gentle and calm.
The gems around him began to glow like a thousand stars.
When the song ended, he felt light and peaceful, as if he’d dreamed while awake.
He whispered, “Thank you,” and the cave whispered back, “Come again.”

Sam and Chipper walked deeper into the forest, where the air grew cooler and damp.
A fog rolled in, wrapping around their ankles like soft blankets.
From somewhere ahead came a low humming, like bees—but slower, almost musical.
Chipper tilted his head. “That’s not normal forest sound…” he whispered.

transitions.text: Climb a tree to look around

story.text:
The humming grew louder until Sam could make out glowing blue lights floating between the trees.
They weren’t bugs—each one looked like a tiny ball of mist.
When Sam reached out to touch one, it darted away, giggling faintly.
Suddenly, one floated close and whispered, “Stay with us forever.”

Sam climbed a tall pine tree, the bark rough under his hands.
From above, he could see the mist forming shapes—faces that smiled and vanished.
In the distance, something sparkled near a pond.
Chipper called up, “I think I found something shiny!”

Sam turned and ran, heart pounding.
The blue lights followed him, whispering softly, “Don’t leave…”
He dove into a bush and covered his mouth, trying not to breathe too loud.
When he peeked out, the forest was quiet again—but he never forgot those voices.

Sam hesitated. “Who are you?” he asked.
The lights hovered closer, forming the shape of a tall, ghostly figure.
It smiled, gently touching his shoulder. “The forest remembers all who wander too deep.”
Chipper squeaked in terror and tugged Sam’s sleeve. They ran until the light faded.

Sam climbed down quickly and joined Chipper by the pond.
A beautiful golden ring lay half-buried in the mud.
When Sam picked it up, it shimmered and hummed softly.
“Maybe it’s magic,” said Chipper. “Or maybe it’s cursed.”

Sam stared at the mist as it twisted into patterns of stars and trees.
It whispered stories of lost travelers and old magic hidden in the soil.
He felt calm but strangely sleepy, his eyelids growing heavy.
When he woke, the mist and Chipper were gone—and the forest was silent.

Sam slipped the ring onto his finger.
At once, he felt lighter—like he could almost float.
Chipper’s eyes widened. “Sam! You’re glowing!”
Sam rose slowly into the air, laughing, as the forest shimmered with color.

Sam tossed the ring back into the pond.
The water rippled once, then went completely still.
“Smart,” said Chipper. “Magic things always come with trouble.”
They walked away, feeling proud and safe.

As the sun began to set, Sam and Chipper spotted an old bridge over a deep ravine.
It creaked with every gust of wind, and one of the ropes looked frayed.
“Should we cross?” asked Chipper.
Sam bit his lip. The shadows beneath looked endless.

The bridge groaned under their feet.
Halfway across, a plank snapped, and Sam grabbed the rope to steady himself.
Chipper squeaked, “Don’t look down!”
Below, something moved—a long, dark shape swimming in the mist.

Sam ran as fast as he could, the bridge swaying dangerously.
With a final leap, he made it to the other side.
The dark shape below rose up—a shadowy bird that screamed and vanished into the sky.
Chipper clapped his tiny paws. “You did it!”

Sam searched along the ravine and found a fallen tree forming a natural bridge.
It was sturdier, though mossy and slick.
They crossed carefully and reached a meadow filled with fireflies.
The moment they stepped in, all the fireflies spelled out his name.

Sam turned back, but the moment he stepped off the bridge, the rope snapped.
The bridge fell into the ravine with a thunderous crash.
He gasped, realizing how close he’d been to falling.
Chipper sighed in relief. “Guess we got lucky!”

After their close call, Sam noticed a trail lined with silver stones.
They glowed faintly under the twilight sky, leading deeper into the woods.
“Looks like someone left these here,” said Chipper.

The stones led them to a giant oak tree with a door carved into it.
Symbols glowed faintly on the bark, pulsing softly.
Chipper touched one, and the door creaked open.
Warm light spilled out, revealing shelves of glowing jars.

Inside the oak, hundreds of tiny lights floated in jars.
Each one flickered like a memory—some happy, some sad.
An old voice said, “Each light is a wish from a traveler.”
Sam placed a finger on one jar, and it glowed brighter.

Sam decided to head home, his adventure enough for one day.
The forest seemed to sigh softly as he left.
When he turned back once, the path behind him was gone.
He smiled anyway, knowing he’d found something special.

Sam turned to run, but the forest around him shifted.
The door in the oak vanished, replaced by twisting roots.
Chipper grabbed his arm. “We have to move!”
They ran until dawn, never looking back.

The next day, Sam returned to the forest with a lantern.
He wanted to see if the glowing stones were still there.
But when he reached the clearing, the ground was smooth and untouched.
Only a single silver pebble remained, shaped like a tiny heart.

Sam squeezed out of the cave into a field of mushrooms that hummed when the wind blew.
Each one emitted a soft note, creating strange music.
Sam smiled, tapping a rhythm with his finger.
The forest seemed to sing with them.

Sam tripped over a vine that slithered like a snake.
Before he could move, it wrapped around his ankle!
He pulled hard, breaking free and falling into soft moss.
When he looked back, the vine was still, as if pretending to be normal again.

A light rain began to fall, making everything sparkle.
Sam laughed and danced while Chipper hid under a leaf.
“Come on!” Sam giggled. “It’s just water!”
A rainbow curved across the trees, ending somewhere deep in the forest.

The rainbow seemed to point toward something glowing faintly in the distance.
“Should we follow it?” asked Chipper.
Sam grinned. “Of course.”
Together they ran toward it, vanishing into a shimmer of colors.

Sam runs under a tree.
He finds an abandoned birdhouse swaying from a branch.
He peeked inside and found a folded note.
It read, “The forest sees kindness.”
He smiled and tucked it into his pocket.

The next morning, Sam returned to the forest.
A soft mist drifted between the trees, and birds called faintly in the distance.
He noticed a small wooden sign that hadn’t been there before.
It read: “Welcome Back, Sam.”

transitions.text: Ignore it and explore on your own

story.text:
The sign pointed toward a crooked path lined with glowing mushrooms.
They pulsed softly, lighting his way like tiny lanterns.
As Sam walked, he heard faint laughter behind him—childlike and echoing.
When he turned, there was no one there. Only his footprints in the glowing soil.

Sam wandered off the trail, curious about a cluster of tall ferns.
The ground felt strangely soft beneath his feet—almost too soft.
Before he could react, it gave way!
He fell into a hidden pit lined with roots and moss.

“Who’s there?” Sam called, his voice trembling slightly.
The laughter stopped. Then came a whisper: “We remember you.”
A gust of wind blew out the mushrooms’ glow, leaving him in darkness.
Something brushed his shoulder—it felt like a feather. Then it was gone.

Sam sprinted ahead until the laughter faded.
He found a clearing filled with giant dandelions that sparkled like stars.
One puffed its seeds into the air—and suddenly he was surrounded by floating lights.
They formed words above his head: “Not all who wander are lost.”

Sam grabbed a root and pulled, but it snapped, covering him in dirt.
Chipper appeared at the edge of the pit, eyes wide. “Hold on, I’ll get help!”
Sam tried to stay calm as roots shifted beneath him.
Then a voice below whispered, “Stay still, or they’ll wake.”

Sam waited, breathing slowly. The pit was quiet except for the sound of dripping water.
He spotted tiny glowing eyes in the darkness.
When he blinked, they were gone—but the faint sound of digging grew louder.
Something was coming up from below.

Sam flicked on his flashlight, cutting through the shadows.
The light revealed dozens of old wooden faces carved into tree trunks around him.
Their mouths were open, and faint mist drifted out.
One tree whispered, “Take only memories, leave only footprints.”

Sam turned and ran until the laughter was just an echo.
He burst from the trees, panting, and saw the edge of the forest at last.
Behind him, the mist closed like a door.
He never found that path again—but sometimes, at night, he heard laughter in the wind.

Sam clawed his way up, dirt crumbling under his fingers.
Just as something brushed his ankle, he grabbed Chipper’s paw and pulled free.
They collapsed on the grass, gasping and shaking.
The pit sealed itself, leaving no trace it had ever existed.

Sam froze. The digging stopped.
Then, slowly, a hand made of roots touched his shoe.
It wasn’t scary—it felt gentle, almost thankful.
When he blinked, he was lying in a field of yellow flowers, safe again.

Later that day, Sam found an old cabin deep in the woods.
Smoke rose from the chimney, and the smell of berries filled the air.
He knocked, and a raspy voice said, “Come in, traveler.”
Inside, a woman with silver hair smiled. “You brought the forest’s light back.”

The tea was warm and tasted like honey and leaves.
The woman hummed softly, and the room shimmered like a dream.
“Tell me,” she said, “what did you learn today?”
Sam smiled. “That the forest is alive.” She nodded, pleased.

Sam bolted from the cabin, heart pounding.
When he looked back, there was no house—only trees swaying in the wind.
He stopped running and laughed nervously.
“Guess I’m imagining things,” he said. But in his pocket was a warm teacup.

Night fell faster than Sam expected.
He realized he’d gone too far and couldn’t find the trail home.
Chipper pointed to a faint glow between the trees. “Maybe that way?”
They followed it and found a field of glowing mushrooms forming an arrow.

The arrow led to a small wooden bridge over a still pond.
Fireflies floated above the water, forming the shape of a heart.
Sam smiled. “I think the forest likes us.”
Chipper nodded. “Maybe it’s saying goodnight.”

They built a tiny campfire with dry twigs.
The night was quiet except for the sound of owls and rustling leaves.
Sam looked up and saw a shooting star streak across the sky.
He made a wish—that he could always come back to this forest.

The next morning, Sam found a trail of paw prints beside the campfire.
They weren’t Chipper’s—these were large, round, and deep.
He followed them to a clearing and found a huge stone shaped like a sleeping bear.
The bear’s stone eyes opened, and it said, “You should not have followed.”

Sam woke with the sunrise, the forest covered in dew.
He stretched, smiled, and watched Chipper chase butterflies.
A cool breeze rustled the trees as if whispering goodbye.
When he reached home, his mom said, “You were gone only an hour.”
But Sam knew better—the forest had its own time.

Years later, when Sam was grown, he took his own children to the forest.
He showed them where the trees touched the sky and where Chipper once lived.
The forest greeted him quietly, a familiar hum in the wind.
And as he smiled, he could have sworn he heard a tiny squirrel giggle, “Welcome back.”

Sam decided to go for a swim.
He finds a river and starts swimming. He closes his eyes and floats, but when he opens them again, he’s on the bank with no idea where home is.

questions.text: What did Sam love to do?
Where did Sam go on his walk?
What were the names of the two creatures Sam met?
What did Aaron want to show Sam?
Would you rather explore with Chipper or Aaron? Explain.

story.text: Kevin did not like his alarm clock. He liked to sleep in his warm bed. Kevin knew he had to do the thing he liked the least. Go to school. He crawled out of his bed and decided to get changed.

transitions.text: Kevin gets dressed in a clown costume
Kevin gets dressed in a suit

story.text: Kevin dresses up in his clown costume. Now Kevin decides it’s time to go downstairs and say good morning to his parents. “Hi Mom, hi Dad!” says Kevin. “Hi Kevin,” they say, his Mom looks at him and says, “Kevin, you are not wearing that to school, go put on some real clothes.”

transitions.text: Kevin gets dressed in his pajamas
Kevin gets dressed in a suit

story.text: Kevin decides to wear his pajamas. Now Kevin decides it’s time to go downstairs and say good morning to his parents. “Hi Mom, hi Dad!” says Kevin. “Hi Kevin,” they say, “Go have some breakfast now,” his mom says.

Kevin decides to wear a suit. Now Kevin decides it’s time to go downstairs and say good morning to his parents. “Hi Mom, hi Dad!” says Kevin. “Hi Kevin,” they say, “You look so professional, little man, go have some breakfast now,” his mom says.
Kevin decides not to eat breakfast, and instead packs his bag and makes his bed. When he goes downstairs his parents stand at the door ready to drive him to school.

transitions.text: Kevin chooses to go with his Mom
Kevin chooses to go with his Dad

Keep on driving and ignore it

story.text: Kevin climbs into the car with Dad. Dad tells so many funny jokes on the way that Kevin can’t think properly.

story.text: Kevin decides to go with Mom, on the way to school, Kevin sees a cat stuck in a tree.

Kevin stops to help the cat

story.text: Kevin decides to go with Dad, Dad drops him off on the block so that he can go to work early.

transitions.text: Kevin walks the long way to school

story.text: Kevin decides to walk to school, on the way to school he sees something shiny in the grass.

transitions.text: Kevin decides to pick it up
Kevin decides to walk by it

story.text: Kevin asks his Mom to pull over, he hops out, grabs the ball and rushes back to the car. In the car he throws the ball up and down. Then Kevin gets to the school and his Mom lets him out.

transitions.text: Kevin leaves the ball in the car
Kevin takes the ball to school

story.text: Kevin looks out the other window and continues to go to school.
Kevin laughs so hard that when he stumbles out of the car and his Dad drives away, he goes all the way to his classroom before he realizes that he forgot his bag in the car.

transitions.text: Kevin goes the day without his bag
Kevin runs after his dad’s car
Kevin goes to the office and calls his dad

story.text: Kevin tells his dad to be quiet and play the radio. His dad silently turns on the radio and finishes the drive silently.

transitions.text: Kevin apologies and tells his Dad to tell jokes

story.text: Kevin decides not to tell his Mom about the cat.
Kevin asks his Mom to pull over so he can help the cat. Kevin climbs up the tree and gets the cat. Kevin is very hungry.
Kevin decides to go straight to school. Kevin walks into his classroom. He sits at his desk.

transitions.text: Kevin talks to the person next to him
Kevin hears a weird humming sound

story.text: Kevin walks around the school and walks into the forest.
Kevin walks over to it and finds a shiny coin.
Kevin decides to walk past the shiny object.
Kevin leaves the ball in the car he skips into the school.

transitions.text: Kevin skips all the way to class

story.text: Kevin takes the ball into the school. He throws the ball up and down. When he’s in the building he throws it up and a massive hairy hand grabs the ball.
Kevin decides to not use his bag. He goes into class and the teacher asks him, “Kevin, where is your bag?” “It’s in my Dad’s car” “Go to the office and call your Dad now.”
Kevin races out of the building and runs after his Dad’s car. He runs and runs and runs but can’t catch up.
Kevin walks into the office and asks to call his Dad. “Do you remember his number sweetheart,” the desk lady asked. You remember two numbers, but you forget which one is your Dad’s.
Kevin walks into class and sits at his desk. The person who sits next to him is at the front of the class talking with her friends. She left an apple on her desk and Kevin is very hungry.

Kevin decides to talk to the teacher. “Good morning, Mrs. Appleton!” Kevin says. Mrs. Appleton smiles, “Good morning, Kevin. I see someone is ready to learn today!” Kevin feels proud and takes out his notebook.
Kevin talks to the person next to him. “Hi, I’m Kevin,” he says. The other student smiles and says, “I’m Mia. Want to see my magic trick?” Kevin nods eagerly.

transitions.text: Kevin ignores it and reads a book

story.text: Kevin stays in the forest. He finds a little stream and sees frogs hopping around. Kevin decides to build a tiny leaf boat for one of the frogs.
Kevin goes to school. He enters the building and bumps into the janitor, who is juggling mops. Kevin laughs and helps catch one of the mops.
Kevin takes the shiny coin. It feels heavier than it looks. Suddenly, it glows and Kevin hears a tiny voice say, “Thank you for freeing me!”

transitions.text: Kevin pockets the coin and goes to class

story.text: Kevin leaves the coin. He keeps walking and notices a funny-shaped cloud that looks like a dragon. Kevin smiles and skips to school.
Kevin skips all the way to class. His friends notice his happy skip and start skipping too. Soon the whole hallway is full of skipping students!

transitions.text: Kevin joins a game of tag
Kevin goes straight to his desk

story.text: Kevin screams and runs. The massive hairy hand belongs to a friendly giant puppet operated by the school drama club. Kevin laughs and joins the puppet performance.
Kevin confronts the ball stealer. It’s a mischievous raccoon wearing a tiny hat! Kevin decides to play fetch with the raccoon.
Kevin notices the classroom window is open and hears a strange humming sound.

Kevin calls his Dad at 905-234-3748.
Dad answers cheerfully and says, “Sorry, buddy! I’ll bring your bag to school.”
Kevin smiles and waits patiently.

Kevin calls his Dad at 905-235-0987.
Dad says, “I’m at work and can’t come!”
Kevin sighs but remembers he packed his lunch in a small backpack anyway.

Kevin takes the apple from the desk.
It tastes delicious and gives him extra energy.
Kevin feels ready for any adventure!

Kevin leaves the apple.
He decides to wait until lunch to eat.
Meanwhile, his stomach rumbles quietly.

Kevin asks a question in class.
Mrs. Appleton nods and says, “That’s a great question, Kevin!”
Kevin feels smart and confident.

Kevin doodles in his notebook.
He draws a funny version of himself wearing a superhero cape.
He giggles quietly at his drawing.

Kevin watches Mia’s magic trick.
She makes a coin disappear and appear behind Kevin’s ear!
Kevin laughs and applauds her trick.

Kevin reads a book.
It’s about a mischievous cat who sneaks into a library at night.
Kevin imagines himself sneaking around like that cat.

Kevin sails the leaf boat.
The frog hops in and rides it across the stream.
Kevin cheers for his new frog friend.

Kevin chases the frogs.
He slips on a mossy rock and lands in the water with a splash!
He laughs and jumps back out, soaked but happy.

Kevin follows the voice.
He finds a tiny fairy trapped inside a coin-sized bubble.
Kevin carefully frees the fairy.

Kevin pockets the coin and goes to class.
He notices it glinting in his bag every so often.
He wonders if it’s just a lucky coin or something more mysterious.

Kevin joins a game of tag.
He runs so fast that he accidentally slides across the gym floor like a superhero.
Everyone cheers, and Kevin feels like the fastest kid in school.

Kevin joins the puppet performance.
He pretends the giant puppet is his secret sidekick.
Everyone laughs and asks him to join the drama club.

Kevin plays fetch with the raccoon.
The raccoon steals a pencil and runs away.
Kevin chases it down, giggling, and ends up leading the raccoon through the playground.

Kevin investigates the humming sound.
He discovers a hidden elevator that leads to a rooftop garden.
He sees the whole school from above.

Kevin waits for Dad to bring the bag.
While waiting, he meets a friendly janitor who shows him a secret shortcut to the playground.

Kevin keeps his small backpack.
He decides to invent a “mini backpack survival kit” with pencils and snacks.
His classmates are impressed by his cleverness.

Kevin feels energized after (or before) lunch.
He decides to start a fun doodle contest with his classmates.

Kevin’s attention drifts during class.
He starts imagining himself as a superhero saving the school from mischievous aliens.

Kevin watches Mia’s trick or reads the book.
He learns a new way to imagine adventures and tells a friend about it.

Kevin’s frog adventure ends.
He decides he wants to bring a little nature project to class.
His classmates cheer when he shows them the leaf boat.

Kevin keeps playing tag.
He wins the game but trips and rolls into a pile of mats.
Everyone laughs, including Kevin, and he takes a bow.

Kevin joins the drama club puppet performance.
He becomes “Puppet Kevin,” the star of the show.
They perform at the school assembly.

Kevin chases the raccoon and retrieves his pencil.
The raccoon gives him a tiny bow as a “thank you gift” and runs off.
Kevin keeps the bow as a lucky charm.

Kevin explores the rooftop garden.
He finds a nest of baby birds chirping loudly.
He gently watches them and decides to tell the teacher about the garden.

Kevin follows the janitor’s shortcut.
He discovers a tiny hidden playground slide.
He slides down with glee and almost bumps into his principal!

Kevin shows off his mini backpack.
Other kids get inspired to create their own mini kits.
Kevin feels proud for being clever.

Kevin starts a doodle contest.
Everyone joins in, creating funny monsters and superheroes.
The classroom turns into a colorful gallery.

Kevin draws his superhero adventure.
He imagines saving the school from a giant cookie monster.
Everyone laughs when he shows them his comic.

Kevin daydreams quietly.
He imagines winning a gold star for being the calmest kid in class.
He smiles to himself and returns to work.

Kevin tells the teacher about the rooftop garden.
The teacher congratulates him for discovering a new school hideout.
They plan a class visit to see it safely.

Kevin slides down the hidden playground slide.
The principal laughs and asks him to help with a “fun obstacle course” event.
Kevin’s doodle contest ends. The teacher praises everyone’s creativity and hangs the drawings on the wall.

Kevin helps set up the obstacle course with the principal.
He becomes the official “fun coordinator” for the day.
Kevin runs around helping students in the obstacle course. He accidentally wins a small prize for being the fastest helper.
Kevin accidentally drops his pencil in class. It rolls under the desk and reveals a hidden treasure map drawn by a past student.
Kevin follows the treasure map during recess. He discovers a tiny box filled with stickers, erasers, and a note saying, “You are brave and clever!”
Kevin finishes looking at the treasure box of stickers and erasers. He wonders what else the school might hide.
Kevin sneaks out to the playground. He sees a small wooden door under the slide.

Kevin just looks at the lanterns. They glow softly and fill the room with pretty colors.

story.text: Kevin starts a treasure hunt for his friends. They split into teams and giggle as they search.
Kevin plays tag with his friends. He runs so fast he trips over a mysterious rock.
Kevin peers inside the hole and sees a small glowing key.
Kevin follows the lantern and finds a tiny fairy garden tucked behind a bush.
Kevin picks up a lantern and carries it to class. It glows in his bag, making everyone curious.

transitions.text: Kevin shows it to the teacher

story.text: Kevin leaves the lanterns alone. The room slowly dims as he walks back to the playground.

transitions.text: Kevin explores more of the playground

story.text: Kevin crawls into the tunnel and finds a secret garden full of flowers and small animals.

transitions.text: Kevin just looks at the garden

story.text: Kevin keeps walking around the playground and discovers a tree with a rope ladder.
Kevin digs up the whole dragon toy. It flaps its tiny wings and squeaks happily.

transitions.text: Kevin takes the dragon to class
Kevin leaves it in the sandbox

story.text: Kevin leaves the dragon half-buried. A tiny note is tucked under it: “Play with care!”
Kevin hides another secret prize: a small shiny marble.
Kevin just watches the hunt. He notices a hidden path behind the swings.
Kevin looks under the rock and finds a tiny map.

transitions.text: Kevin keeps it in his pocket for later

story.text: Kevin keeps playing tag. He runs past a tree and finds a small door carved into the trunk.
Kevin grabs the glowing key. It feels warm in his hand.

transitions.text: Kevin searches for the lock it belongs to
Kevin puts it in his pocket for later

story.text: Kevin talks to the fairies. They giggle and give him a tiny crown.
Kevin just looks quietly. He sees the fairies dancing and waving.
Kevin shows the lantern to the teacher. She smiles and says it’s a “magic classroom helper.”

transitions.text: Kevin lights the lantern during class
Kevin keeps it on his desk without lighting

story.text: Kevin keeps the lantern secret. He notices it glows softly when he writes in his notebook.

transitions.text: Kevin writes a secret message to the lantern

story.text: Kevin follows the rabbit and finds a tiny door in a tree.

transitions.text: Kevin follows the rabbit back to the garden

story.text: Kevin just looks at the garden. He sees butterflies and hears birds singing.

transitions.text: Kevin collects a flower to show his class
Kevin leaves the garden as it is

story.text: Kevin climbs the ladder and finds a treehouse full of old toys.

transitions.text: Kevin explores the treehouse for secrets

story.text: Kevin takes the dragon to class. It flaps its tiny wings and makes the other kids laugh. Kevin’s dragon becomes the class mascot for the day.
Kevin leaves the dragon in the sandbox. He waves goodbye as he goes back to play.
Kevin reads the note: “Play with care!” He smiles and decides to be careful with the dragon.

transitions.text: Kevin takes the dragon to class

story.text: A friend finds the marble and thanks Kevin. They both giggle and hide it again.
No one finds Kevin’s secret prize. He tucks it in his pocket and keeps exploring.

transitions.text: Kevin looks for more hidden treasures

story.text: Kevin explores the hidden path behind the swings and finds a small pond.

transitions.text: Kevin skips stones on the pond
Kevin looks into the pond for fish

story.text: Kevin follows the map and finds a tiny treasure chest buried under a tree root.
Kevin keeps the map in his pocket for later. He wonders what adventure it could lead to.

transitions.text: Kevin goes back to play with friends

story.text: Kevin opens the tree door and finds a spiral staircase leading down.
Kevin searches for the lock the key belongs to and finds a tiny treasure box under a bench.
Kevin puts the key in his pocket for later. He wonders if it will be useful soon.
Kevin joins the fairy dance. The fairies twirl around him and sprinkle glowing dust. Kevin feels magical and dances all the way back to class.
Kevin lights the lantern during class. It glows softly, and everyone’s work looks brighter. Kevin’s class has a super fun, glowing day of learning.
Kevin keeps the lantern on his desk. He notices small shapes glowing inside it.

transitions.text: Kevin makes up a story about the shapes

story.text: Kevin writes a secret message to the lantern. It sparkles and changes color as he writes.

transitions.text: Kevin shares the message with a friend

story.text: Kevin watches the lantern glow quietly. He feels peaceful and happy.

transitions.text: Kevin draws the glowing shapes in his notebook

story.text: Kevin opens the tiny tree door and finds a spiral staircase.
Kevin collects a flower to show his class. It smells sweet and brightens his bag. Kevin shares the flower with his teacher and feels proud.
Kevin leaves the garden as it is. He smiles and walks back to class.
Kevin plays with the toys in the treehouse. He finds a toy rocket and imagines flying to space.

transitions.text: Kevin takes the rocket to class
Kevin leaves it in the treehouse

story.text: Kevin explores the treehouse for secrets and finds an old diary.
Kevin starts a marble game with friends. They laugh and play for a long time. Kevin becomes the marble champion of the playground for the day.
Kevin skips stones on the pond. One stone skips five times and lands perfectly.
Kevin looks into the pond and sees a tiny frog waving at him.

transitions.text: Kevin ignores it and keeps walking

story.text: Kevin opens the tiny treasure chest. Inside is a sparkling gem. Kevin shows it to his friends and feels like a real treasure hunter.
Kevin leaves the chest alone. He wonders who hid it.
Kevin goes down the spiral staircase and finds a glowing cave full of friendly fireflies.
Kevin opens the treasure box under the bench. Inside is a tiny golden pencil. Kevin uses the golden pencil to draw magical pictures in class.
Kevin makes up a story about the glowing shapes in the lantern. Kevin shares his story with the class, and everyone claps.
Kevin shares the secret message with a friend. They giggle and make up more secret messages together. Kevin and his friend have a fun, sneaky adventure for the rest of the day.
Kevin keeps the secret message. He smiles quietly and writes more.
Kevin draws the glowing shapes in his notebook. His teacher notices and praises his creativity. Kevin feels proud for making such a beautiful drawing.
Kevin keeps staring at the lantern. It sparkles softly and makes him feel calm.
Kevin climbs down the staircase and finds a tiny underground library.

transitions.text: Kevin explores the library for more secrets

story.text: Kevin takes the toy rocket to class. He pretends it’s real and flies around his desk. Kevin imagines an amazing space adventure with his classmates cheering.
Kevin reads the diary and finds stories about old school adventures.

transitions.text: Kevin writes his own adventure in the diary

story.text: Kevin keeps skipping stones. He sees the reflection of the clouds in the pond.

transitions.text: Kevin draws the clouds in his notebook

story.text: Kevin explores the pond edge and finds a small wooden boat.
Kevin talks to the frog. The frog hops onto his hand and croaks a funny tune. Kevin makes a new animal friend for the day.
Kevin chases the fireflies. They lead him to a tiny door in the cave wall.
Kevin watches the fireflies quietly. They light up the cave beautifully. Kevin feels peaceful and amazed by the glowing fireflies.
Kevin reads a book from the underground library. It tells a story about a secret school adventure.
Kevin explores the underground library and finds a secret passage behind a bookshelf.
Kevin writes his own adventure in the diary about hidden treasures. Kevin imagines himself as a hero explorer every day in class.
Kevin draws the clouds from the pond in his notebook. They look magical on the page. Kevin feels proud of capturing a special moment from nature.
Kevin decides to go on the boat. He sails down the river and he lies down on the wood and takes a nap. When he opens his eyes again, he’s back at school!
Kevin opens the door, inside it is a bright white light. Kevin steps through it and on the other side is his classroom. His teacher walks and tells him it’s time to go home.

Kevin jumps around and acts out the story when he’s done he goes further and further into the underground library. Along the way he acts out more books. Eventually his teacher finds him and takes him back.
Kevin reads the book quietly. He keeps on reading books and goes further and further into the library. Kevin never finds his way back out.
Kevin crawls through the bookshelf and finds a tiny door.

questions.text: What does Kevin like the least?
What does Kevin wake up in?
Would you wear a clown costume to school? Explain.
